name: Zbigniew Żedzicki
description: Zbigniew Żedzicki had the following finishes at major championships – 1970 World Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (4th); 1971 World Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (5th); 1968 European Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (3rd); 1975 European Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (3rd); 1970 European Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (4th); 1967 European Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (5th); 1973 European Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (5th).

name: Wilfried Siegele
description: Wilfried Siegele was Austrian champion in 20 km walk (1979 and 1980) and 50 km walk (1981-1984). His brother Hans was Austrian champion in 10 km track walk (1978), 20 km walk (1978), and 50 km walk (1980, 1985, and 1986). Personal Best: 20kmW – 1-28:17 (1980).
special_notes: Brother of Hans Siegele

name: Joshua Millner
description: Jerry Millner was the son of a highly successful wool merchant and woolen manufacturer, and eventually took over the family business. The 61-year-old Millner is the oldest Britain ever to have won an Olympic gold medal, a distinction he achieved at Bisley in 1908 when he son the free rifle event with a score of 98 points out of a possible 100. Miller took a serious interest in competitive shooting in 1871 and in 1874 was a member of the Irish team which visited the United States. In the match against the Americans, Millner began with a bulls-eye but unfortunately it was on the wrong target and the four points deduced for Millner’s error virtually cost the Irish the match as the host country won by only three points. Jerry Millner visited America again in 1887 when the British team lost the Palma Match at Creedmore by 93 points. He also represented Ireland in the Elcho Match for thirty years and captained the team in 1919, although he did not actually compete that year. Millner was a distinguished figure in the Territorial Army. He served as a lieutenant in the Finsbury Rifles from 1882 to 1887 and then joined the famous Carlow Militia which was by then a territorial regiment of the King’s Royal Rifle Corps. The Carlow Militia was finally disbanded in 1908 with Millner as their last Commanding Officer, having been colonel of the Regiment for the past 15 years. Lieutenant Colonel Millner served as a member of the Council of the National Rifle Association from 1907 to 1914. In retirement he became known as a breeder of Irish Setters, judging the breed at many dog shows, and writing the first book on the breed, The Irish Setter, Its History and Training, published in 1924.

name: Garibaldo Nizzola
description: Garibaldo Nizzola had the following finishes at major championships – 1951 World Championship: 67.0 kg. Freestyle (2nd); 1957 World Championship: 73.0 kg. Freestyle (6th).
special_notes: Son of Marcello Nizzola Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–0 1951 Al-Iskanderiya WRE silver: freestyle lightweight -67 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Received the Italian Olympic Association (CONI) Gold Medal ()

name: Gerhard Aßmus
description: Gerhard Aßmus was a trap shooter from Leipzig. He finished in a tie for 17th place at the 1960 Roma Summer Olympics in trap shooting. Aßmus competed for ASK Vorwärts Leipzig with the United German team.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–1–0 1962 Al-Qahira silver: trap team (competed for East Germany))

name: Robert Jaworski
special_notes: Father-in-law of Mikee Cojuangco-Jaworski Listed in Olympians Who Were Members of National Legislatures (Member of 11th and 12th Congress of the Philippines from 1998 through 2004 (Independent))

name: Gladys Eastlake-Smith
description: There were only seven competitors in the 1908 Olympic covered court women’s singles and in only her third match of the tournament, Gladys Eastlake-Smith met Alice Greene in the final. After two sets the match was level but Eastlake-Smith won the final set 6-0 to take the gold medal. Neither of the finalists was in the absolute top flight of British players but Eastlake-Smith certainly had the better indoor record of the two. She won the All-England covered court singles in 1907 and was again a finalist in 1908 when she lost to Dorothy Lambert Chambers who did not enter the Olympic events. Miss Eastlake-Smith also won the All-England covered court mixed doubles in 1905 with Reggie Doherty and again in 1908 with Tony Wilding. Two days after her Olympic victory, Gladys Eastlake-Smith married Wharram Lamplough and in 1913 they won the now defunct married Doubles championship.

name: Herman Goffberg
description: Herman Goffberg finished third in the AAU 6 miles in 1942 and 1948, and fourth in the 3 miles in 1944. He was third in the 1948 Olympic Trial 10K. He competed for Eastern Michigan University, Penn State, the Shanahan Catholic Club, the Penn Athletic Club, and the US Coast Guard. At Penn State he helped the Nittany Lions to finish second in the 1941 NCAA cross-country championships, the 1942 IC4A indoor track championships, and the 1942 IC4A outdoor track championships. Goffberg married Indian-British actress Janine Gray who appeared in numerous movies and television shows, although they divorced after only a few years. Goffberg eventually lived in London where he started out selling cars, but then evolved into an import-export business. Later in life he returned to State College, Pennsylvania, living there in his twilight years, and worked for the track team as a “graduate manager.” Goffberg was also president of the Penn State Varsity “S” Club in 1995. Personal Best: 10K – 33:10.0 (1948).

name: Imre Alker
description: Imre Alker had the following finishes at major championships – 1967 World Championship: 52.0 kg. Greco-Roman (3rd); 1963 World Championship: 52.0 kg. Greco-Roman (6th); 1965 World Championship: 52.0 kg. Greco-Roman (6th); 1968 European Championship: 52.0 kg. Greco-Roman (5th); 1970 European Championship: 52.0 kg. Greco-Roman (6th).

name: Manuela Secolo
description: Manuela Secolo was an Italian volleyball spiker who began her career in the 1991/92 season with Albatros Volley of Treviso in Serie B1. She continued playing in lower leagues with Polisportiva Mogliano, Ages Volley San Donà, Forlimpopoli, Olimpia Ravenna and Robursport Pesaro, with whom she won the Cadet Series Italian Cup. It was not until the 2003/04 season, when she joined Bergamo, that Secolo made her Serie A début. In four seasons with Bergamo, she won two championships, the Italian Cup, Italian Super Cup, CEV Cup, and two Champions’ League titles (2005 and 2007). Secolo moved to Chieri in the 2007/08 season before playing abroad for a season with Olympiakos of Greece. She returned to Italy in 2009/10 and won the Italian Cup again, this time with Villa Cortese. In 2010/11 she wore the vest of the newly promoted Universal Modena, before another move, to Crema, and in 2012/13 she won the Championship and Italian Cup with River, of Piacenza. She stayed in Piacenza the following season, playing with Piacentina in Serie B1. Between 2004-09 Secolo won 76 Italian caps. In addition to competing in two Olympics, she won a gold medal at the 2007 European and World Championships, and also a bronze medal in the World Grand Prix that year. She repeated the Grand Prix bronze medal the following year and in 2009 won the European gold medal again, as well as winning gold at the Mediterranean Games in Pescara, Secolo retired from competitive volleyball at the end of the 2013/14 season and, in January 2016, she and her basketball-player husband Andrea Bianchi had a daughter, Matilda.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 2009 Pescara VOL gold) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Volleyball Championships (2–0–0 2007 BEL/LUX gold; 2009 POL gold)

name: Yuan Li
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–0–1 1999 Seoul bronze: foil team)

name: Percy Beard
description: At the 1932 Olympics, Percy Beard was in the lead until he hit the sixth hurdle and ended up losing by a very narrow margin to George Saling. Beard had won the first of three AAU high hurdles titles in 1931, posting a new world record of 14.2 for 120 yards. Over the 110 meter distance, he equalled the world record of 14.4 in the 1932 Olympic Trials and during a European tour in 1934 he lowered the record to 14.3 and then to 14.2 After graduating from Auburn as a civil engineer, he ran four outdoor and five indoor seasons for the New York AC, losing only one race in all. He won the AAU indoor hurdles in 1931, 1932, 1933 and again in 1935. Beard went on to earn a master’s degree from Auburn and taught engineering there from 1929 to 1935. He then moved to the University of Florida as track coach and became athletic director before his retirement in 1973. The University of Florida track is named for Percy Beard. Personal Best: 110H – 14.2y (1931).

name: Guglielmo Pesenti
description: Guglielmo Pesenti had bicycles in his blood. His father Antonio (1908-68), a legendary climber, won the 1932 Giro d’Italia. At school Guglielmo competed in a lot of sports, but in his mind there was only cycling, although his father discouraged it. At the beginning he raced and won on the roads but, in 1951, at the Vigorelli Velodrome in Milano, he won a sprint trophy and the Italian track coach wanted him on the Azzurri track squad at only 18-years-old. Pesenti left school and became a track sprinter. He was formidable and set four world records in the 200 and 500 metres, but he was a crafty strategist in the sprint and used that trait to win the 1956 sprint silver medal at the Melbourne Olympics and place third at the World Championships in København. One year later in Rocourt he finished second at the Worlds. Pesenti was also a five-time Italian champion (two in sprint, two in tandem and, as a pro, a winter title), also adding many victories in European Grand Prixs.

name: Brian Magee
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1998 Kuala Lumpur BOX bronze: middleweight -75 kg (competed for Northern Ireland))

name: Masaaki Kaneko
description: Masaaki Kaneko had the following finishes at major championships – 1966 World Championship: 63.0 kg. Freestyle (1st); 1967 World Championship: 63.0 kg. Freestyle (1st); 1966 Asian Games: 63.0 kg. Freestyle (1st).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 1966 Bangkok WRE gold: freestyle featherweight -63 kg)

name: Mannie McArthur
description: Mannie McArthur grew up playing for the Eastern Suburbs RUFC, helping the Warriguls win the premiership in 1901. He then played for one year with Randwick before returning to Eastern Suburbs. Captaining the club in 1908 he was chosen for the Wallabies tour of the British Isles and France, during which time he played in the 1908 London Olympics, helping Australia to a gold medal. He played in 15 of 38 matches during the tour. Upon returning Down Under, many of his teammates switched to professional rugby league, but McArthur played with Eastern Suburbs until 1914 when World War I suspended most rugby in Australia. After the war McArthur coached the Easts, helping them to the first-grade premiership in 1931. McArthur was a successful insurance broker with New York Life Insurance Group.

name: Fouad Yazgi
description: Fouad Yazgi had a brief career in track athletics, with his most notable international appearance coming at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics. There, he was eliminated in the first round of both the 110 metres hurdles and the 4x100 metres relay, in the latter alongside Emad Shafei, Fawzi Chaaban, and Youssef Omar. Domestically, he was the Egyptian national champion in the 110 metres hurdles in 1952 and 1953. Yazgi immigrated to Canada in 1966, where he often went by the name “Fred”. He settled in Quebec and, in 1975, joined Ingersoll-Rand, where he eventually rose to the position of Regional Manager of Eastern Canada. Personal Bests: 100 – unknown; 110H – 15.2 (1953).

name: Alfredo Lemus
description: Alfredo Lemus had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1975 Pan American Games light-middleweight.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1975 Ciudad de México BOX bronze: light-middleweight -71 kg)

name: Marian Wnuk
description: Polish sculptor, educator and artistic activist Marian Wnuk studied woodcarving at the School of Wood Industry in Zakopane and then sculpture at the School of Fine Arts in Warszawa. Until World War II, Wnuk was employed as a teacher at the National Institute of Fine Arts in Lvov and collaborated with the underground council of Polish Jews. After the uprising of Warszawa, he was deported to a forced labor camp in Germany. After the war Wnuk was appointed professor and rector of the Academy of Fine Arts of Gdańsk in Sopot, and later in Warszawa. He was known for his monumental sculptures, and in his later works, he retained his classical solutions, achieving exceptional expression. This allowed him to adapt well to Socialist Realism.

name: Brian Lewis
description: Brian Lewis was a sprinter who won a gold medal with the USA 4x100 metre relay team at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. Lewis also won gold in the short relay at the 1999 World Championships and the 1995 World University Games. He competed at the 1998 Goodwill Games, winning a bronze medal in the 100 metres. Lewis was in the USA top 10 in the 100 metres in 1998, ranking #10, and 2000, ranking #4. He was runner-up at the USA Championships in the 100 in both 1998 and 1999, finishing fourth in 2000, and fifth in 1997. Personal Best: 100 – 9.99 (2002).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 1995 Fukuoka ATH gold: 4×100 m relay (ran in heats only)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1999 Sevilla gold: 4×100 m relay)

name: Francisco Lázaro
description: The legendary first marathon runner, Pheidippides, died after completing his run. The modern Olympics revived the legend in 1896 and, sadly, a death also occurred in an Olympic marathon. Francisco Lázaro, Portugal’s best long-distance runner at the time of the 1912 Stockholm Olympics, was the victim. A winner of the 1910 Lisboa marathon and Portuguese national champion from 1910-12, Lázaro was used to running in hot circumstances, like on the day of the Stockholm marathon. He thought he could improve his performance by not sweating and greased up his body for the race. This had an adverse effect, as his body could not cool down. Just after the half-way point, Lázaro fell for the first time, and stopped walking straight. After 30 kilometers, he eventually collapsed, and did not get up. A doctor was quickly at the scene, and the unconscious marathon runner was quickly carried to the Seraphim hospital. He was taken in with a body temperature of 41 degrees Celsius. Intensive care all through the night could not revive him, and he died around 6 AM, causing a shock to the other athletes and the general public. The following weekend, a memorial service was held in the Olympic Stadium, with 23,000 in attendance. Some $3800 was collected for Lázaro’s wife, and a monument was placed at the marathon’s turning point at Sollentuna. In Portugal, his funeral was attended by thousands. Although always known as Francisco Lázaro, it turns out that he was baptized Francisco da Silva and “Chico do Lázaro” was only a nickname. Personal Best: Mar – 2-52:08 (1912).
special_notes: Listed in Athletes Who Died During the Olympics (Collapsed and died of overheating during competition, caused by Lázaro greasing up his body for the race.)

name: Brad Hauser
description: Brad Hauser was a distance runner who ran the 5,000 metres at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. He ran in college at Stanford, graduating with a degree in human biology. At Stanford Hauser won the 1998 NCAA 10,000 metres and was second in the 1999 NCAA 5,000 metres. He also finished second in the 10K at the 1999 USA Championships. Hauer was 14th at the 1996 World Junior Championships in the 10K and placed 21st in the event at the 1999 World Championships. He ran twice at the World Cross-Country Championships, in 2000 and 2001, with a best finish of 15th in the 2000 short-course event. Hauser had a twin brother, Brent, who also ran distances for Stanford. Personal Best: 5000 – 13:27.31 (2000).

name: Nikola Simeonov
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-19:47 (1968).

name: Alfred Jauch
description: Alfred Jauch of Basel came on to the wrestling scene in 1940 when he won the national junior lightweight title at the 1940 Greco-Roman wrestling championships in Lausanne. The runner-up to 1936 Olympian Oskar Holinger in the lightweight class at the 1945 Swiss Greco-Roman wrestling championships, he was selected for the Swiss national team in 1948 to compete at the London Olympics. There, he unfortunately did not see much success, withdrawing from the first round. Jauch continued to compete throughout the 1950s and won his only Swiss Greco-Roman title, in the welterweight class, in 1951. He also wrestled in the freestyle category, though did not win any titles.

name: Noemi Batki
special_notes: Daughter of Ibolya Nagy Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 2007 Bangkok DIV gold: 1 m springboard) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (0–4–1 2008 Eindhoven DIV bronze: synchronized platform; 2010 Budapest DIV silver: platform; 2012 Eindhoven DIV silver: platform; 2014 Berlin DIV silver: platform; 2018 Edinburgh DIV silver: platform) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Diving Championships (2–0–2 2011 Torino gold: platform; 2015 Rostock bronze: platform; 2017 Kyiv bronze: synchronized platform (mixed); 2019 Kyiv gold: synchronized platform)

name: Thorsten Johansen
description: In addition to the gold medal that he won at the 1920 Olympic Games in the team running target, double shot event, Thorsten Johansen was a member of the Norwegian team that took the title at the 1929 world championships in the same event. Johansen was a gunsmith by trade.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (2–0–0 1929 Stockholm gold: 100 m running deer single shot team and 100 m running deer double shot team)

name: Sven Salén
special_notes: Husband of Dagmar Salén

name: John Zimmerman
description: John Zimmerman was a professional figure skater who specialized in pairs. He competed at the 2002 Salt Lake City Winter Olympics with Kyoko Ina, finishing fifth. Zimmerman started in pairs in 1994 with Brie Teaboldt but then skated with Stephanie Stiegler from 1995-98, finishing third at the 1997 US Nationals and the 1997 Skate America. Stiegler and Zimmermann broke up as a pair and he joined up with Ina in 1998. They were US Champions in 2000, 2001, and 2002, placing third at the 2002 World Championships. Together Ina and Zimmermann had several other podiums at major events, including second place finishes at the 1999 Trophée Lalique and 2000 Skate Canada and Four Continents, and in 2002 they were second at Tropée Lalique, Skate America, and Sparkassen. In 2003 Ina and Zimmermann joined Stars on Ice and skated in ice shows for several years. He also skated on several television figure skating shows, in 2006 in “Skating with Celebrities” with FOX sportscaster Jillian Barberie, and in 2010 in the ABC show “Thin Ice”, in which he paired with former Canadian Olympic ice dancer Shae-Lynn Bourne. Zimmerman became a figure skating coach, working in Coral Springs and Wesley Chapel, Florida alongside his wife, Silvia Fontana, a former Italian Olympic figure skater. In 2018 he coached the pair of Vanessa James and Morgan Ciprès. In December 2019 Zimmermann, Fontana, and another coach, Vinny Dispenza, were accused of covering up sexual abuse committed by Ciprès. In March 2021 Zimmermann was suspended by US SafeSport for two years and given one year of probation in which he could not coach skaters or attend US skating events.
special_notes: Husband of Silvia Fontana Listed in Olympians Who Acted in Movies (Small part in Blades of Glory.) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Figure Skating Championships (0–0–1 2002 Nagano bronze: pairs)

name: Rusty Mitchell
description: Rusty Mitchell attended Southern Illinois University, where he specialized in tumbling, winning NCAA titles in that in 1962, the last two years that tumbling was an NCAA event. He also won the 1964 AAU title in tumbling, and won US Gymnastics Federation championships in 1965-66 in all-around, floor exercise, and tumbling. He later coached at the University of New Mexico for 33 years. Mitchell was the coach at both the 1974 World Championships and the 1973 Universiade. He also became a men’s vice-president of USA Gymnastics and was in charge of men’s gymnastics at that organization. Mitchell served gymnastics in multiple administrative roles, serving on the US Olympic Committee, the National Association of College Gymnastics Coaches, the National High School Rules Committee, and the National Collegiate Sport Council. In 1978 he was inducted into the Southern Illinois Hall of Fame. He was inducted into the US Gymnastics Hall of Fame in 1985.

name: Paulo Catarino
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-12:20 (1997).

name: Alphonse Hercule Matam
special_notes: Brother of Samson N'Dicka-Matam Brother of David Matam Brother of Bernardin Matam

name: Wang Liqin
description: Wang Liqin has won nearly all possible titles in the sport of table tennis. Joining the Chinese team at age 15, he first made his name as a doubles player, but later became one of the top singles players as well. At the Olympics, Wang won a gold in the 2000 doubles tournament, bronzes in the 2004 and 2008 singles, and captured the first ever Olympic team title when his sport came home in Beijing. At the World Championships, he has won titles in all four events, winning the singles in 2001, 2005 and 2007, the doubles in 2001 and 2003, the mixed doubles in 2005 and 2007, and the team competition in 2001, 2004, 2006 and 2008. Wang has never won the World Cup (he was a runner-up in 2001), although he did win the team World Cup in 2011. He also won four gold medals at the Asian Games, and has been Asian champion eight times between 1998 and 2009.
special_notes: Bearer of the Olympic Flag at the opening ceremony of the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics

name: Clement Deykin
description: Clement Deykin was one of the forwards in the Moseley Wanderers team at the Paris Olympics and was, at the time, the only current County player in the team. In one four day spell between 24-28 October 1900 he played for the Midland Counties against East Midlands and three days later played for his club-side Moseley against Coventry. Within 24 hours he crossed the Channel to play in the Paris tournament, and then return to England! Deykin was a manufacturing jeweller by trade and in 1901 he launched a revolutionary machine, after six years of research and development, for manufacturing rings in a fraction of the time it previously took to make them by hand.

name: María Far
special_notes: Daughter of Alfredo Far

name: Caspar Springer
description: Personal Best: 400 – 47.2 (1972).

name: Federico Marietti
description: Federico Marietti made his début for the Italian basketball team against France in 1948. In a four-year career, he won 39 international caps, and scored 139 points. Marietti competed in the 1948 and 1952 Olympics when Italy finished 17th on each occasion.

name: Olaf Hense
description: Olaf Hense was a 400 hurdler who was eliminated in the heats at the 1992 Barcelona Olympic Games. He was a bronze medal winner with the German 4×400 relay at the 1993 World Championships in Stuttgart. He competed in the 400 hurdles at the 1991, 1993 and 1995 Worlds and 1990 Europeans, but never reached a final. Hense was German Champion in the 400 hurdles in 1991, 1992 and 1995, also winning in 1992 with the 4x400 relay. Indoors he won the title in 1993, adding relay wins in 1993 and 1998. Hense was educated as a fitter, studied mechanical engineering, and later headed a glass construction company. He also became chairman of the sports foundation in his hometown of Schwerte. Hense married Tina Balke and became the son-in-law of 800 runner Jörg Balke and his wife Rosemarie Klute. Personal Best: 400H – 48.48 (1993).
special_notes: Son-in-law of Jörg Balke Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (0–0–1 1993 Stuttgart bronze: 4×400 m relay)

name: Benny Brown
description: Ben Brown of UCLA finished in fourth place at the 1976 Final Trials in the 400 metres. This earned him a spot on the 1,600m relay team and he ran the third leg in 44.6 in the Montréal final. Brown had won the 1975 NCAA 400 meter championship. He was killed in a car accident. Personal Bests: 200 – 20.6 (1975); 400 – 44.7y (1973); 800 – 1:48.8 (1986).

name: Irvin Ternström
description: Personal Best: 100 – 10.5 (1937).

name: Ivan, Viscount d'Oyley
description: Until recently, Viscount d’Oyley was considered a French fencer. Recent research has revealed, however, that Alastair Ivan Ladislaus Lucidus Evans was an American, the son of well-known Parisian-based American dentist, Dr. John Henry Evans. Viscount d’Oyley is not known to have represented any French club in 1900 fencing, so he is likely best termed an American entrant. John Evans followed his uncle, Dr. Thomas Wiltberger Evans, to Paris. Thomas Evans had become famous as a dental surgeon to nobility and was able to amass a fortune in Parisian real estate. John Evans moved from his native Baltimore to Paris in an attempt to set up a similar lucrative dental practice. He succeeded, working on Pope Leo XIII, who bestowed on him the title of Marquis d’Oyley. John Evans also stole several of his uncle’s patients, however, and after he succeeded to the nobility, enjoyed riding around in Paris in a magnificent carriage with a coat of arms and yellow-stockinged footmen. His uncle promptly disowned him and wrote him out of the will. Due to his father’s titles, Ivan Evans was also bestowed as the Viscount d’Oyley. In 1904 he took up with the Peruvian Madame Pflucker, who he met in Vichy. They sojourned to Cannes, and stayed on the Riviera for some time together, against John Evans’ protests. The father cut Ivan off any income and the couple returned to Paris, staying at the Hotel de Rivoli. There, Viscount d’Oyley died, the victim of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The original story was that this was a suicide attempt, although later reports from his father stated he did not die by his own hand. Madame Pflucker confirmed the suicide theory, producing two letters he had addressed to authorities stating he intended to commit suicide.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Committed Suicide (Died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.) Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Viscount d'Oyley)

name: Nteboheleng Koaeana
description: Personal Best: 100 – unknown.

name: Dietmar Koszewski
description: Hurdler and sprinter Dietmar Koszewski was eliminated in the semifinals of the 110 hurdles at the 1992 Barcelona Olympic Games. He participated at the 1991 and 1993 Worlds, placing seventh in 1993, and winning a bronze medal at the 1990 Europeans. Indoors Koszewski started at the 1990 Worlds and the 1989, 1990 (4th) and 1992 Europeans. Domestically he won West German and German titles in 1989 and 1993 (runner-up 1990-92), also winning indoors in 1993 in the 60 m. He studied physics at the Technical University of Berlin. Personal Best: 110H – 13.41 (1990).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 1993 Buffalo ATH gold: 110 m hurdles) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–0–1 1990 Split bronze: 110 m hurdles (competed for West Germany))

name: Alfons Dorner
description: West German cross country skier Alfons Dorner appeared only once at the Winter Olympics, in 1964, when he finished 34th in the 30 km event. Dorner became a policeman and later owned a sports goods shop in his hometown Reit im Winkel. He also opened a cross country learning school.

special_notes: Nephew of Olavi Linnonmaa

name: Raúl Castañeda
description: Raúl Castañeda competed as a light-flyweight at the 2004 Athina Olympics. He continued to compete as an amateur and won a bronze medal at the 2007 Pan American Games. Castañeda actually started competing as a professional in 2005, winning his first bout on 1 October. He fought professionally through 2012, finishing with a record of 15 wins (8 by KO) and 2 losses. In May 2009 Castañeda fought Mario Rodríguez for the WBC Continental Americas Minimumweight title, but lost by decision. Castañeda had difficult times in later life, and was arrested several times for robbery. He was killed in 2017 in what appears to have been a drive-by shooting.

name: Asa Dogura
description: Attending Kyoto Girls High School, Asa Dogura represented Japan at the Los Angeles Olympics, placing fifth with the Japanese 4x100 metre relay team. She later married fellow 1932 Olympian Naoto Tajima, who was to become gold medalist in the triple jump at the Berlin Olympics four years later. At the age of 93 Dogura died from cancer. She was said to be the model for a character in the novel The Fruit of Olympus published in 1940 by Hidemitsu Tanaka, well-known novelist and rowing Olympian. Personal Best: 100 – 12.5 (1932).
special_notes: Wife of Naoto Tajima

name: Stephanie Berto
description: Stephanie Berto had the following podium finishes at major championships: 1st in the 1971 Pan American Games 200 metres, 2nd in the 1971 Pan American Games 100 metres. Personal Best: 100 – 11.4 (1971).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–1–0 1971 Cali ATH gold: 200 m, silver: 100 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1970 Edinburgh ATH bronze: 4×100 m relay)

name: John Hamber
description: John Hamber played football for San Jose State University. He then joined the US Marine Corps and played football for the Marine Corps team at Quantico, Virginia, and was named to the All-Marine All-Stars. Hamber helped with the formation of Force Recon (FORECON – the Marines Special Forces) and graduated #1 in his Army Ranger School, and later graduated #1 in a Navy underwater dive class that would evolve into the Navy Special Forces, the SEALs. Hamber was honorably discharged from the Marines in 1960. An avid sailor, he owned and operated John Hamber’s Watersports in the Virgin Islands in the 1960’s and 1970’s.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–1–0 1966 San Juan SAI silver: Flying Dutchman)

description: Personal Best: TJ - 14.58 (1936).

name: Begoña Gumucio
special_notes: Sister of Arantza Gumucio

name: Bente Moe
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-32:36 (1987).

name: Clark Leiblee
description: Clark Leiblee was a sprinter who competed for the University of Michigan and the Detroit AC. He was third in the AAU 200 in 1901. Leiblee also played football at Michigan, as a halfback. In addition to competing in the 100 metres at the 1900 Paris Olympics, Leiblee ran in the 100 metre handicap non-Olympic event. Leiblee died young in an automobile accident. Personal Bests: 100y – 10.0 (1900); 100 – 10.9e (1900).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Died in Motor Vehicle Accidents (Boat/Car/Motorcycle/Train) (Died in an automobile accident.)

name: Michael Warriner
description: Michael Warriner went up to Trinity College, Cambridge from Harrow and was in the winning Cambridge boat in 1928, 1929 and 1930, his last year as President of the Cambridge University Boat Club. Other successes included victories at Henley in the Visitors’ in 1928 and the Stewards’ and the Ladies’ in 1929. In 1930 like many rowing blues of the time, Warriner joined the Sudan Government Service but returned to England in 1934 and entered the business world as an engineer. In the war, he was, at first, with the Indian Army but he then served in Greece and the Middle East as a Lieutenant Colonel in the REME. He was awarded the MBE in 1945.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Competed in the Boat Race (1928 Cambridge (won), 1929 Cambridge (won), 1930 Cambridge (won))

name: Horst Kilian
description: Horst Kilian, twin brother of Günter Kilian, played for the West German water polo team that finished sixth at the 1976 in Montréal Olympics. In total, he earned 147 international caps between 1969 and 1979. He helped SV Würzburg 05 to win five West German national titles (1970, 1974, and 1976-78).
special_notes: Twin brother of Günter Kilian

name: Frederic Moore
description: Frederic Moore was the captain of the six-man team that won the gold medals in the 1908 Olympic clay pigeon team event. He also placed equal seventh in the individual event. A leading figure in British clay pigeon shooting for much of the 1890s and 1900s, Moore served as the president of the English Inanimate Bird Shooting Association (IBSA) in the late 1890s and as captain of the English national team for many years. He was first involved with the St. George’s Gun Club in the 1890s, then with the Middlesex Gun Club for the next two decades, serving as its chairman in 1914. Moore worked with James Lyle & Co. on Old Bond Street in London and was a tea and coffee merchant by profession. He was also involved in organizations such as the St. George’s Harmonic Club and The Universal Cookery and Food Association. Born in Dorset, he was the son of a musician and organist, William Walling Moore.

name: Bayano Kamani
description: Personal Best: 400H – 47.84 (2005).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 2007 Rio de Janeiro ATH silver: 400 m hurdles) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 1999 Palma de Mallorca ATH silver: 400 m hurdles (competed for the United States)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (1–0–0 2006 Cartagena de Indias ATH gold: 400 m hurdles)

name: Dorothy Hey
description: Dorothy Hey was one of four Saltaire gymnasts to finish in the top six at the first post-World War II national gymnastics championship. Hey, who was just 16 at the time, finished sixth, and was subsequently one of four Saltaire members selected for the 1948 Olympics, the others being Irene Hirst, Audrey Rennard, and the 1936 Olympian, Clarice Bell (née Hanson). The British women’s team coach, Carrie Pollard (née Pickles), was also from Saltaire. The British women finished ninth in the all-round team competition. In 1949, Hey was a member of the Saltaire team that won the British Drill Team Championship. She married local cricketer Derek Webster in 1952 and was originally chosen for the Helsinki Olympics that year. However, due to work commitments as a hairdresser, she could not attend a training weekend at Cardiff, and pulled out of the squad. She was asked if she was willing to be a non-travelling reserve, which she agreed to. However, after Pat Hirst developed glandular trouble after arriving in Helsinki, Dorothy got a last-minute call to travel to Finland, just six days before the start of gymnastics events. Hirst eventually recovered, and took part, leaving Hey side-lined. After marrying Webster, and having a family, Derek and Dorothy moved away from their native Yorkshire to work on farms around the country, only to return to their roots in the 1970s. Their son John was an international speed skater, while another son was a successful local footballer.

name: Mario Franke
description: German gymnast Mario Franke was on the reunified team that finished a surprising fourth at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. Individually he came 50th and did not advance to an apparatus final. His best result was the 13th place on the rings. In 1993, he collected his only national titles on the parallel bars and the rings. Franke later turned to coaching and became Regional Coach at the Hessian Gymnastics Association.

name: Donna Kellogg
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (3–1–2 1998 Kuala Lumpur BDM gold: doubles and team women, bronze: mixed doubles (competed for England); 2002 Manchester BDM gold: team mixed (competed for England); 2006 Melbourne BDM silver: team mixed, bronze: doubles (competed for England))

name: József Hátszeghy
description: József Hatz was born into a military family. Their parents sent all four of their boys into military service. His brother, Ottó, was also a military officer and an Olympic fencer. Later, they all changed their names to Hátszeghy. Staring from 1934, Hátszeghy was a fencer with MAC, while from 1935-44 he was with Honvéd Tiszti Vívóklub, and between 1946 to 1948 was a part of Újpesti TE. He won the Hungarian individual foil championship in 1937, 1943, and 1944, finishing second nine times. From 1936-44 he won the foil team championship nine times. Between 1933 and 1942 he appeared 20 times on the Hungarian national team. He was second at the 1933 European Championship with the Hungarian foil team. As a member of the Hungarian Olympic foil team, Hátszeghy finished seventh in Berlin in 1936 and fifth in London in 1948. Hátszeghy was a professional military officer. He and his family were arrested for his anti-German activity during the war and taken to prison first in Hungary and then in Austria, only to be released from German captivity through the intercession of Otto’s brother. After his release, he served in the Army and between 1948 and 1952 and became commander of the famous sports squadron. From 1953 to 1959 Hátszeghy was the fencing master of Bp. Elektromos, and from 1960-71 had the same role with Újpesti Dózsa. In 1972-73 he was a fencing coach in Algeria, from 1974 to 1978 he was the fencing master of BSE, and from 1979 to 1988 he was fencing master of Budapest Honvéd.
special_notes: Brother of Ottó Hátszeghy

name: Dave Hudson
special_notes: Father of Roger Hudson

name: Dave Gorsuch
description: Dave Gorsuch competed for the US at the 1958 World Championships and the 1960 Winter Olympics. He skied for Western State College, winning the 1963 NCAA downhill title, and placing second that year in slalom and combined. Gorsuch later married US ski team member Renie Cox. Together they settled in Colorado, founding Gorsuch Ltd., a specialty ski and retail shop in Gunnison. It became a popular shop with several outlets and in 1966 they moved to Vail. In Vail Dave and Renie Gorsuch became leaders of the ski community, managing Gorsuch Ltd., helping raise funds to build Vail Valley Medical Center, and helped establish the Vail Mountain School and Ski Club Vail. He served on numerous boards and civic commissions, including the Vail Planning Commission, Ski and Snowboard Club Vail, Vail Mountain School, and the Colorado Snowsports Museum. Gorsuch was inducted into the Colorado Business Hall of Fame and the Colorado Snowsports Hall of Fame. He was also a distant relative of US Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch.
special_notes: Husband of Renie Cox

name: Philip Bowden-Smith
description: Philip Bowden-Smith was an all-round horseman. He was equally at home playing polo, show jumping, competing in three-day-events, riding with the hunt, or taking part in point-to-point races. He was also an excellent bloodstock breeder. At the 1924 Olympics, Bowden-Smith competed in both the eventing and show jumping competition, and in the individual jumping event finished fourth on his mount Billy Boy, missing out on a bronze medal by just 0.5 of a point. At Berlin 12 years later, he was captain of the Great Britain eventing team that won the bronze medal, although he did not compete. The son of Colonel Edmund Bowden-Smith, Philip, affectionately known as “Bogey”, attended Military College before being commissioned into the 19th (Queen Alexandra’s Own) Hussars in 1910. He fought in both World Wars and between 1949-59 was colonel of The Queen’s Royal Lancers and retired with the rank of brigadier. Honoured with the CBE, he was at one time an instructor at the Cavalry School, and was also the senior instructor at the Army’s Equitation School at Weedon. After the war Bowden-Smith was an aide-de-camp to King George VI. In the 1930s Bowden-Smith was a show jumping judge at the Olympia Royal Tournament, and was also the Northern divisional member of the County Polo Association. He was also a good standard golfer with a single-figure handicap, and regularly played in the Cavalry Club Championship.

name: Bud Havens
description: Bud Havens competed in the canoeing demonstration events at the 1924 Paris Olympics. He won the kayak singles, kayak doubles, and kayak fours, and finished second in the Canadian fours. Havens was a former Mid-Atlantic wrestling champion. His brother was Bill Havens, who was also supposed to compete at Paris, but stayed home so he could be there for the birth of his first child, Frank Havens, Frank later won a silver and gold medal in the C-1 10K in 1948 and 1952, respectively. When he won his gold medal in 1952, he sent his father a telegram that read, “Dear Dad, thanks for waiting around for me to get born in 1924. I’m coming home with the gold medal you should have won. Your loving son, Frank”. Bud Havens was also the uncle of Bill Havens, another of Bill’s sons, who also competed in canoeing at the 1948 Olympics.
special_notes: Uncle of Frank Havens Uncle of Bill Havens

name: John A. Russell
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Competed in the Boat Race (1956 Cambridge (win))

name: Tamara Tikhonova
description: Tamara Tikhonova made her international début at the 1985 World Championships, where she won a gold medal as a member of the Soviet relay team. Tikhonova missed the 1987 World Championships, but competed again at the 1988 Olympic Winter Games, where she won golds in the 20 km and relay, a silver at 5 km and was fifth over 10K. At the 1989 World Championships, Tikhonova won a silver in the relay, a bronze in the 10 km freestyle and was 11th in the 30 km freestyle. Tikhonova made her last international appearance at the 1991 World Championships, where she won gold in the relay and was third in the 10 km freestyle. Tikhonova also won a bronze at the 1988-89 World Cup. After retiring from sports in 1992 Tikhonova has worked as a cross-country skiing coach in her native Udmurtia.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (1–0–0 1987 Štrbské Pleso CCS gold: 5 km) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Nordic Ski Championships (2–1–2 1985 Seefeld CCS gold: 4×5 km relay; 1989 Lahti CCS silver: 4×5 km relay, bronze: 10 km freestyle; 1991 Val di Fiemme CCS gold: 4×5 km relay, bronze: 10 km)

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 2015 Toronto WLT bronze: lightweight -69 kg)

name: Albert Cooper
description: Albert Cooper was a football goalkeeper who played for Trenton FC. He earned four caps for the United States, initially playing in the 1928 Olympic match against Argentina. After the Olympics, he played in a friendly against Poland, which ended in a 3-3 tie. He later played for the Trenton Highlanders, who won the 1937 American Cup title, and this enabled the Highlanders to be selected to compete in the inaugural football tournament at the first Pan American Games, though unofficial, in 1937 in Dallas, Texas, representing the United States. Cooper also played in two matches at those Games. Cooper was a New Jersey native, being born in Trenton, and later dying in Vincentown, New Jersey.

name: Laura Asadauskaitė
special_notes: Wife of Andrejus Zadneprovskis

name: Sonja Henie
description: Sonja Henie was the first superstar of women’s figure skating, winning three Olympic gold medals in 1928, 1932, and 1936. She made her Olympic début in 1924 when only an 11-year-old. She finished last in a field of eight but improved to fifth a few weeks later at the 1924 World Championship. Henie finished second at the 1926 World Championships to Austria’s Herma Plank-Szabo, but she then won the championship for the next ten years consecutively. She did more to popularize figure skating than any other individual. Henie turned professional in 1936 and soon amassed a fortune. Her flair for showmanship ensured the success of the ten feature films she made in Hollywood and accelerated the public awareness of ice skating as a sport. She toured the world with spectacular ice reviews achieving great popularity, particularly in the USA. She was initially idolized in her native Norway, but had some image problems after World War II when she was perceived to be a Nazi sympathizer who failed to support war relief efforts in Norway. Henie married three times, all to very wealthy men, and her own earnings from ice shows made her one of the richest athletes ever. She later suffered from leukemia and died during a flight from Paris to Oslo where she was flying to visit a specialist.
special_notes: Cousin of Marit Henie Listed in Olympians Who Acted in Movies (Notably in the Oscar nominated One in a Million.) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Figure Skating Championships (6–0–0 1931 St. Moritz gold: singles; 1932 Paris gold: singles; 1933 London gold: singles; 1934 Praha gold: singles; 1935 St. Moritz gold: singles; 1936 Berlin gold: singles) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Figure Skating Championships (10–1–0 1926 Stockholm silver: singles; 1927 Oslo gold: singles; 1928 London gold: singles; 1929 Budapest gold: singles; 1930 New York City gold: singles; 1931 Berlin gold: singles; 1932 Montreal gold: singles; 1933 Stockholm gold: singles; 1934 Oslo gold: singles; 1935 Wien gold: singles; 1936 Paris gold: singles)

name: Marie Brun
description: Marie Chevalier-Brun was a member of the Société de sport de Compiègne, with the 1900 Olympic golf tournament held at the Compiègne Club. She shot 80 for nine holes to finish 10th and last. Marie Chevalier was the daughter of Martial Elie Simon Chevalier (1816-1892), who was, at various times, the consul général de France to Canada, Italy, and Switzerland, a ministre plénipotentiaire, and an officer of the légion d’honneur. She married Armand Emile Brun (1849-1929) on 27 February 1888.

name: Eva Široká
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1965 Budapest VOL bronze) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Volleyball Championships (0–0–1 1967 TUR bronze)

name: Mohamed Gouni
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–0 1979 Split WLT silver: featherweight -60 kg)

name: Michael Bates
description: Michael Bates was a bronze medalist in the 200 metres at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, and also won two gold medals, in the 100 and 4x100 relay, at the 1991 Universiade. He is best known as a football player in the United States. In 1989 and 1990 he won the Pac-10 Championships in both the 100 and 200 metres. Bates played college football at the University of Arizona. He was drafted in the sixth round of the 1992 NFL Draft by the Seattle Seahawks and played with them through 1995. From 1996-2000 he was with the Carolina Panthers, making All-Pro every year and being named to the Pro Bowl for five consecutive years. He was primarily known as a kick returner and was named to the NFL All-Decade Team for the 1990s as a kick returner. He was of only five NFL players to lead the league in kick return average for two seasons. Bates played in the NFL through 2003, finishing his career with stops with Washington Redskins, back with the Panthers from 2003-03, and finally with the New York Jets and Dallas Cowboys. His brother, Mario, played seven seasons in the NFL for the New Orleans Saints, the Arizona Cardinals, and the Detroit Lions. Personal Best: 200 – 20.01 (1992).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (2–0–0 1991 Sheffield ATH gold: 100 m and 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Played in the NFL (Seattle Seahawks (1993-94), Cleveland Browns (1995), Carolina Panthers (1996-2000), Washington Redskins (2001), Dallas Cowboys (2003), New York Jets (2003))

name: Giacomo Bazzan
description: Giacomo Bazzan, originally from Vescovana in Padova, followed his older brother Nereo as a cyclist, He started his career whilst a student as an amateur with the Velo Club Mantovani Rovigo. He then moved on to the Cyclists of Padova and as a professional to the Jolly Ceramica team from 1973 onwards. Bazzan achieved his most important successes as an amateur, twice winning the Italian championship in team pursuit (1970-71) and he was part of the world champion quartet in 1971 at the Varese velodrome. In the same edition of the World Championship he won the bronze medal in individual pursuit. At the subsequent 1972 München Olympics the Italian team suffered great disappointment when the world champions could only finish ninth in qualifying and were eliminated before the quarter-finals. As a professional Bazzan was one of Italy’s top pursuit riders on the track and represented his country at three World Track Championships narrowly missing out on the podium on two of those occasions. On the road he was used as a domestique supporting more talented road riders and usually had a busy campaign throughout the season. He rode the Giro d’Italia three times and the Tour de France once, achieving a handful of top 10 stage finishes and an overall best of 62nd at the 1975 Giro. After he concluded his competitive career, Bazzan was president of the Rovigo committee of the Federciclismo for two terms and collaborated with the FCI (Italian Cycling Federation) and the Italian Olympic Committee. By profession he was an entrepreneur in the textile sector. He passed away on Christmas night 2019 after a short illness. In honor of his sporting achievements, Bazzan was awarded a Gold Medal by the Italian Olympic Committee.

name: Forest Fletcher
description: Forest Fletcher competed for Notre Dame and later the 1st Regiment AA. He earned a degree in electrical engineering from Notre Dame while captaining the track team. Fletcher began teaching math and coaching at Mitchell High School in South Dakota and then at Utah State Normal School. In 1914 he came to Washington and Lee University where he established the university’s physical education department. He taught at W&L for 28 years before retiring in 1942 due to poor health. Fletcher was one of the group that helped form the Southern Conference in 1921. He was President of the Southern Conference from 1934-36. Personal Bests: sHJ - 1.45 (1912); sLJ - 3.22 (1912).

name: Andreas Steiner
description: Andreas Steiner was Austrian champion in long jump (1987 and 1988). Personal Best: LJ – 8.30 (1988).

name: Robert Monier
description: Robert Monier was the son of a wine-merchant and became one himself. Prior to World War I, he was an excellent rugby player, representing France twice internationally. In 1911 he played against Ireland and in 1912 against Scotland. Monier also won the French Championships twice with Stade Bordelais (1909, 1911).

name: Franz Thannheimer
description: Franz Thannheimer was a cook and was made responsible to bring on and cook the food for the 1928 Winter Olympic team in their preparations for the Olympic qualifying races. At the 1928 St. Moritz Winter Olympics he came in 17th in the normal hill event. In 1927 he won the New Year Jump at Oberstdorf with the new hill record of 46 m. In 1928 he set a new unofficial world jumping record of 75 m. At the 1929 World Championships, he placed 20th. He ran a carpenter’s shop in his hometown of Oberstdorf, and on his death, the business was taken over by his son.

name: Yosvel Iglesias
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2003 Santo Domingo ROW gold: lightweight quadruple sculls)

name: László Orczán
description: László Orczán started his cycling career at the age of 17 with Törekvés SE, and then competed in the colors of the club throughout his career. He also did speed skating as an additional sport, and in 1933 finished fourth in the Hungarian speed skating championship. In cycling he initially competed mainly in road races. At the age of 18 he won the Budapest-Siófok 100 km road race, then at the age of only 19, in 1931, he triumphed in the individual road race championship. In 1933, he was third in the Tour de Hongrie and was a member of the Hungarian team that won the team competition. However, despite his road success, he continued to race on the track. In 1935 and 1936 he won the national championship in the 1000-metre time trial and in 1937 finished first in sprint. In 1936, Orczán set a world record in the 1,000-metre time trial, so he went to the Berlin Olympics as a favorite, but finished fifth in the kilometre time trial and seventh in the team pursuit. After World War II, Orczán coached in the cycling department of MTE, and in speed skating also served as a judge.

name: Eric de Bruin
description: Competed in 1988 Olympic Baseball demonstration event.

name: Yvonne Tobis
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–1 1966 Bangkok SWM silver: 200 m medley, bronze: 100 m freestyle)

name: Pavel Frinta
description: Pavel Frinta had the following finishes at major championships – 1990 World Championship: 82.0 kg. Greco-Roman (5th); 1994 World Championship: 82.0 kg. Greco-Roman (6th); 1991 World Championship: 82.0 kg. Greco-Roman (13th); 1995 European Championship: 82.0 kg. Greco-Roman (6th); 1994 European Championship: 82.0 kg. Greco-Roman (12th); 1996 European Championship: 82.0 kg. Greco-Roman (12th).

name: Mireille Cayre
description: Mireille Cayre was a French gymnast who competed at the 1968 and 1972 Olympic Games. She also participated at the 1966 World Championships in Dortmund. She later served gymnastics in several roles, working as a judge at the Olympics and other international competitions, and also as a sports administrator. Cayre served as regional technical director on the Marne island from 1975-81. From 1975-78 she was commissioned in gym dance studies at the Paris Opera, and she then became a director in the Drôme-Ardèche from 1981-86. She was technical director in Auvergne from 1986-88, charged primarily with preparing juniors for the European Championships. Cayre stayed in Auvergne as a director from 1988-94, and then from 1994-2009 was technical director of the Central French Zone, before retiring at the end of 2009. In 2002, Cayre received the Gold Medal of Youth and Sports.

name: Ian Thorpe
description: Ian Thorpe first came to International prominence at the 1997 Pan-Pacific meet when he finished second in the 400 freestyle. He was then 14 years old. At the 1998 World Championships he won both the 200 and 400 freestyle, and was the media darling of Australia going into the Sydney 2000 Olympics. He won three gold medals at the 2000 Olympic Games, but his only individual title was in the 400 free, as he finished second in the 200 freestyle. With three relay medals, he won five Olympic medals at the Sydney Games. At the 2001 World Championships, he won the 200, 400 and 800 metre freestyle events, all in world record times, and also swam on three winning relay teams, becoming the first person to win six gold medals at a single World Championship. At the 2002 Pan-Pacific meet, Thorpe won five titles – three individual in the 100, 200, and 400 freestyles, and two relay championships. He has set 13 individual world records (through 2006). Although slightly overshadowed by Michael Phelps, Thorpe won four more Olympic medals at the 2004 Athens Olympics, with golds in the 200 and 400 metre freestyles.

name: Andy Sudduth
description: Andrew Sudduth grew up in Exeter, New Hampshire and started rowing at Phillips Exeter Academy. He attended Harvard University, graduating in 1983. He led his Harvard crew to the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley, but after college, began sculling. In addition to his Olympic silver medal, he won a bronze in eights at the 1986 World Championships and pulled a single to a silver medal at the 1985 World Championships. Sudduth rowed on the US National Team for eight years and won four medals at the World Championships. He became a legend at the Head of the Charles Regatta, winning the singles for five consecutive years, and was also known for his ergometer records at the CRASH-B sprints. When his rowing career faded, he turned to long-distance cycling to stay in shape. Sudduth’s career was in computers, and he helped develop server technology that was instrumental to the success of the Internet. He died fairly young from pancreatic cancer.

name: Nikola Dimitrov
description: After taking up the sport in his youth during World War II, Nikola Dimitrov joined the Levski Sofia football squad in 1924 and remained with them until his retirement in 1940. During that time, he won Bulgarian First League titles in 1933 and 1937, the Ulpia Serdika Cup four times (1926, 1930-1932), and the Sofia Championship five times (1924, 1925, 1929, 1933, and 1937). He also earned five international caps for Bulgaria. Following his retirement from active competition, he worked as a coach. Football was not Dimitrov’s only talent, however, as he won numerous national championships in Nordic combined. He competed at two editions of the World Championships, in 1933 and the unofficial 1941 edition, and was also selected to represent his country in this event at the 1936 Garmisch-Partenkirchen Olympics, although he failed to start the event.

name: Douglas Robinson
description: The son of Irish-born parents, Douglas Robinson’s father was Sir William Cleaver Francis Robinson, and his grandfather was Admiral Hercules Robinson. Douglas’ father was the governor of Montserrat from 1862, and Robinson was born there. He later lived in the Dominica, the Falkland Islands, Leeward Islands and Western Australia, after his father accepted other postings. Douglas went on to become a notable painter, sportsman and soldier. He joined the Navy as a midshipman at the age of 13 and rose to the rank of lieutenant-commander, but left to study painting in Paris, where he became an expert water colour artist, specializing in landscapes. When the Boer War broke out Robinson joined the Army and went on to become a Major. During World War I he was captured and, during his time as a prisoner-of-war at Loos, he painted many landscapes from his cell window. A keen sportsman, Robinson was at home on a horse as he was with a cricket bat in hand. Sadly, his cricket record, playing for France at the 1900 Olympics, saw him dismissed for a “pair” – two ducks. As a bowler, however, he succeeded in claiming the wickets of John Symes and Alfred Powlesland in Great Britain’s first innings. Robinson died at the German Hospital at Dalston in East London. Robinson was definitely a British national in 1900, but he entered the Olympic cricket match while playing for the French side, Union des Sociétés Français de Sports Athletiques, although in Britain he was a member of the combined team made up of players from the Union Club and the Standard Athletic Club that joined with the French side for the Olympic match.

name: Shota Khabareli
description: At the 1980 Olympics Georgian Shota Khabareli won his only international title. Besides his Olympic gold, Khabareli won bronze at the 1983 World Championships and two silvers (1979 and 1982) and two bronzes (1981 and 1983) at the European Championships. Domestically, Khabareli won three Soviet titles (1982, 1983 and 1985). After finishing his sporting career Khabareli worked as a judo coach in his native Georgia. From 1997-2009, and since 2010, he was head coach of the Georgian national judo team and was named three times (2003, 2006 and 2007) as the best European judo coach of the year by the European Judo Union. Khabareli was also the vice-president of Georgian judo Federation.

name: Yojiro Muro
description: Personal Best: 100 – 10.70 (1961).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 1961 Sofia ATH silver: 4×100 m relay)

name: Vladimir Krylov
description: Vladimir Krylov was the best Soviet all-around sprinter at the end of 1980s. He made his international début at the 1985 IAAF World Cup, finishing fifth in the 400 metres. At the 1986 European Championships, Krylov was third with the Soviet 4x400 m relay team and surprisingly won the 200 metres. He added a silver medal in the sprint relay at the 1987 World Championships. At the 1988 Seoul Olympics, Krylov reached the semifinals of the 100, but won a gold medal as a member of Soviet 4x100 m relay team. Krylov made his final major international at the 1990 Europeans, where he finished seventh in the 100. Domestically, Krylov won six Soviet titles – 100 m in 1990; 200 m in 1986 and 1988; and 400 m in 1984-86. Personal Best: 100 – 10.13 (1988).

name: Teee Sanders-Williams
description: Teee Sanders-Williams, whose mother definitely bought too many vowels when she was born, played college volleyball for the University of Hawai’i. She played for the USA from 1990-96, including at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics. Sanders-Williams won golds with the US team at the 1995 Canada Cup and World Grand Prix, a silver at the 1995 Pan American Games, and bronzes at the 1990 World Championships, the 1992 Olympics, and the 1992 FIVB Super Four. She played professional volleyball in the 1990s in Germany, winning the national indoor title with USC Münster, and in 2003 won the German beach volleyball title alongside Ines Pianka.

name: William Smith
description: William Smith, a veteran of the Second Boer War, was a sergeant with the Governor General’s Foot Guards when he was selected to represent Canada at the 1908 Summer Olympics. He had the highest individual score among his teammates Charles Crowe, William Eastcott, Harry Kerr, Dugald McInnes, and Bruce Williams in the military rifle team event and helped them take the bronze medal in the event. The following year, at Britain’s prestigious Bisley tournament, he won the Daily Graphic Cup by earning the highest score with seven shots at 200 yards. He remained active in sporting shooting through the 1910s and served during both World Wars, the second in the capacity of an aircraft inspector. Later in life he was employed at The Ottawa Journal.

name: Beniamino Vignola
description: Because of his skill and agility, Beniamino Vignola was compared to Italian legend Gianni Rivera as a youngster. Vignola started his career at Hallas Verona and joined Juventus from Avellino in 1983. He was used as a substitute at first, but then broke into the starting line-up on a regular basis and helped Juve win Serie A and the UEFA Cup-winners’ Cup in the 1983/84 season. He scored one goal and set up Boniek’s winner in the Cup-winners’ Cup final win against Porto in Basel. The following season he won the European Super Cup with Juventus, and was part of the European Cup victory over Liverpool, remembered largely for the death of 39 people before the start of the match at the Heysel Stadium, Bruxelles in 1985. Vignola played in five matches for Italy at the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, and scored two goals, as Italy finished fourth. He never won a senior Italian cap. Vignola retired in 1991 with 347 club appearances, and 47 goals to his credit.

name: Ivan Tregubov
description: Ivan Tregubov and Nikolay Sologubov were considered one of the strongest defense pairs in the world at the end of the 1950s. Tregubov was called to CSKA Moskva by his Army friend Sologubov in 1952 and he played with them until 1962. He then spent the next two seasons with SKA Kuybyshev and his career ended in 1965, after a severe leg injury, while playing with Khimik Voskresensk. With CSKA Moskva, Tregubov won six Soviet Championships titles (1955, 1956, 1958-61). Internationally, besides his Olympic gold, Tregubov was a World Champion in 1956, won silver in 1955 and 1957-59, and bronze in 1961, also winning European Championships in 1955-56, and 1958-59. In 1958 and 1961 Tregubov was selected as the best defenseman in the world.

name: Gretchen Ulion
description: Gretchen Ulion played hockey and lacrosse at Dartmouth, leading the hockey team to the Ivy League Championship in 1990-91 and 1992-93, and she was twice named Ivy League Player of the Year. She played on the US National Team from 1993-98. Ulion graduated from Dartmouth with a degree in history, also earning a masters’ degree in education, and later taught at the Pingree School in Massachusetts.

name: Horst Nickel
description: East German biathlete Horst Nickel from Oberhof competed at the 1960 Squaw Valley Winter Olympics, finishing 17th in the only event in that era, the 20 km. Nickel also competed in the 1961 and 1962 Worlds. He was one of the pioneers of biathlon in Thuringia and later turned to coaching.

name: Mario Loch
description: Mario Loch was a German flyweight boxer who was eliminated in the second round at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. In 1991, he was runner-up at the European Championships to the 1996 Olympic bantamweight gold medallist István Kovács. Loch won the East German national title in 1988 and 1989, and also the German title after reunification in 1992. The following year Loch retired at the early age of 23 years. He later worked as a construction worker and barman.

name: Kathy Kelley
description: Kathy Kelly competed in the 1936 Olympics while still a student at Keowee High School in Seneca, South Carolina. Kelly qualified for the Olympic Team by winning a jump-off for the third spot over Ida Myers, both having jumped 5-0½ [1.53]. She attended Greenville Women’s College, which later became part of Furman University. Per college policy, she was forced to leave the school after she married in December 1938. She then took up basketball, playing for Lonsdale Mill’s team in Seneca, South Carolina, which often competed in the Southern Textile Basketball Tournament. Kelly eventually became a beautician. Personal Best: HJ – 5-1¼ [1.55] (1936).

name: Mickey Luce
description: Mickey Luce went to school at Saranac Lake High School, where he played football and was All-Northern New York selection at halfback, and later the State University of New York at Plattsburgh, graduating in 1965. He competed at the 1965 and 1967 World Championships and was an alternate to the 1966 World team. Luce rode on the winning sled at the 1967 International Diamond Trophy race. He later became a social studies teacher in secondary school in upstate New York and coached several sports. In 1978 he left social studies teaching and established the Lake George Youth Theatre program, which he directs.

name: Uwe Mönkemeyer
description: Middle- and long-distance runner Uwe Mönkemeyer won a bronze medal at the 1983 European Indoors in the 3,000 and placed fourth in 1984 for his best international results. In 1986, he also came in fourth in the 1,500, and one year later was eliminated in the heats, but he finished 10th in the 3,000 metres at the World Indoors. In his only Olympic competition Mönkemeyer did not finish the 5K semifinal at the 1984 Los Angeles Games. Domestically, he won two West German championships in 1986 and 1987 in the 1,500 metres, and also won four cross-country titless (1981-84, and 1988). Indoors he added six more national titles. Personal Best: 5000 – 13:21.14 (1986).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Indoor Championships (0–0–1 1983 Budapest bronze: 3000 m)

name: Marcelo Ríos

name: Ulrich Moissl
description: Ulrich Moissl was a German field hockey player who participated in the 2000 Olympics at Sydney. Germany beat Great Britain 4-0 to win the match for fifth place. In 1994 and 1997, he won the European Indoor Championship. In total, Moissl played 100 international matches (including ten indoor) from 1998-2000. Domestically, Moissl played with Dürkheimer HC, and from 2000 with SC Frankfurt 1880. He helped Dürkheim win the German indoor title three times in 1997-98, and 2000. By profession, he became a graduated biochemist.

name: Darrick Heath
description: Darrick Heath started in college at Finger Lakes Community College in New York, before attending C. W. Post College, where he played basketball. He started playing handball with the Garden City club on Long Island, and quickly moved up to the US National Team. He won national titles with Garden City in 1988, 1989, and 1993. From 1993-95 he played professionally in Europe, first with the Elektromos Club of Budapest and then in Graz, Austria. Heath stayed on the US National Team through 2003. He worked from 2001-11 with the Boys & Girls Clubs of Metro Atlanta. In 2011-12 he was coach of the US National Team Handball team. Heath also worked as a lecturer at Emory University from 2002-12.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1991 La Habana HAN bronze)

name: Herbert Kirchner
description: East German biathlete Herbert Kirchner from Oberhof competed at the 1960 Squaw Valley Winter Olympics, finishing 13th in the only event in that era, the 20 km. As Kirchner started with jersey #1 he was the first ever biathlete in the history of Olympic Winter Games. He was one of the pioneers of biathlon in Thuringia and later turned to coaching.

name: Yury Larionov
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Figure Skating Championships (0–1–2 2011 Bern bronze: pairs; 2012 Sheffield silver: pairs; 2014 Budapest bronze: pairs)

name: Ernest Thorne
description: Ernest Thorne was just one of three members of the City of London Police team to make their Olympic début in 1920. The others were Harry Stiff and George Canning. Thorne pulled in all three matches, against the United States, Belgium and Netherlands, which the police team, representing Great Britain, won 2-0 each time.

name: Zoe Atkin
special_notes: Sister of Izzy Atkin

name: Olesya Aliyeva
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (0–1–0 1999 Poprad Tatry ALP silver: Super G)

name: Luis García
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–2–1 1962 Kingston FEN silver: foil and épée team; 1966 San Juan FEN bronze: foil team)

name: Emil Flecken
description: Emil Flecken studied in Dusseldorf and Munich. He traveled from 1926-30 through France, Algiers, the Canary Islands and the island of São Tomé and Angola. He later became a teacher at the Cologne Werkschule (Crafts School). His portraits and studies of nature were initially under the spell of academic paintings in the early 20th Century. Although Flecken progressed during the 60 years of his artistic creativity, he never succumbed to the influence of the trends and fashions of European painting. His painting Fencer’s Salute was still owned by his wife in 1979.

name: Hitomi Kashima
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Short-Course Swimming Championships (25 m) (0–1–0 1997 Göteborg silver: 200 m butterfly) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–0–2 1998 Bangkok SWM bronze: 100 m butterfly and 200 m butterfly)

name: Zhou Wanfeng

name: Marcus Vinícius
description: Marcus Vinícius was a member of the gold medal winning team at the 1983 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1983 Caracas VOL gold)

name: Peter Larisch
description: Peter Larisch was on the East German handball team at the 1972 München Olympics that unfortunately lost the bronze medal match, 19-16, against Romania. He earned 11 international caps. Domestically, Larisch played with SC DHfK Leipzig, helping them to win the 1972 East German Championships. He then moved to SC Einheit Halle-Neustadt and BSG Post Schwerin. In 1980, he was the top scorer in the East German Oberliga with Schwerin. Larisch trained as a waiter and later owned a restaurant at Goldberg. His son Kay-Peter also became a handball player.

name: Tomasz Jędrusik
description: Personal Best: 400 – 45.27 (1988).

name: Jozef Beständig
description: Pairs: 1998 World Championships (18); 1999 World Championships (17); 2000 World Championships (18); 2001 World Championships (FNR); 2005 World Championships (15); 1997 European Championships (17); 1998 European Championships (12); 1999 European Championships (10); 2000 European Championships (13); 2001 European Championships (7); 2002 European Championships (13); 2005 European Championships (8) (with Oljga Beständigová [SVK]).

name: Paula Deubel
description: Paula Deubel attended Springfield College but at the time the school had no women’s track team so she represented Little Rhody Athletic Club, and also represented the Women’s Athletic Association and the Women’s Physical Education Majors Club & Drill Team. She was US Junior Champion in 1953 and won the 1954 AAU Indoors with the shot. Deubel placed fourth in the shot at the 1956 AAU Meet. She was the first Springfield College woman to make a US Olympic team, and was elected a member of the Rhode Island Sports Hall of Fame. Personal Best: SP – 45-7 [13.89] (1956).

name: Bill Carr
description: Bill Carr of Penn and Mercersburg Academy went to the the 1932 IC4A with a best time for the 440y of no better than 48.4, but at Berkeley he caused a major upset by beating the world record holder, Ben Eastman. He again beat Eastman at the AAU, which also served as the Final Trials that year, and crowned the season, which he had begun as an unknown, by winning the Olympic title. Once more the runner-up was Ben Eastman and this time Carr took Eastman’s world record with a 46.2 clocking. Carr then anchored the winning U.S. 1,600 meter relay team to another world record of 3:08.2. Soon after the Olympics, Bill Carr was seriously injured in an automobile accident and never ran competitively again. Throughout his career, albeit a tragically brief one, Carr was never beaten over the one-lap distance. Carr served as a Naval Officer in the Pacific in World War II. He met his future wife, Rachel, in Shanghai, near the end of the war. The couple moved to Japan, where Carr worked for several insurance companies. In 1964 he was inducted into the Arkansas Hall of Fame. He died of congestive heart failure in his sleep while on vacation in Japan. Statues at both Mercersburg Preparatory School and the University of Pennsylvania track stadium (Franklin Field) were erected in his honor. Personal Best: 400 – 46.28 (1932).

name: Árpád Nemessányi
description: Árpád Nemessányi had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1964 European Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (450.0 kg).

name: Olga Potapova
